title.value: Energy Sufficiency in Unknown Environments via Control Barrier Functions
title.justification: The title is directly extracted from the paper and succinctly encapsulates the main theme of the research, which is to ensure energy sufficiency in unknown environments using Control Barrier Functions.
title.quote: Energy Sufficiency in Unknown Environments via Control Barrier Functions

description: The paper presents a framework based on Control Barrier Functions (CBFs) to ensure energy sufficiency of robots navigating unknown and unstructured environments. The framework can be integrated with various path planners, including those used for exploration missions. It guarantees that robots will not run out of energy during their missions, validated through both simulation and real-world experiments.

type.justification: The paper involves simulation experiments and real-world tests on robots to validate the proposed energy sufficiency framework, which aligns with the characteristics of empirical research.
type.quote: The framework is validated through physics-based simulation and on a physical AgileX Scout Mini rover.

primary_research_field.justification: The research focuses on energy sufficiency for battery-powered robot systems, which falls under the field of robotics.
primary_research_field.quote: Maintaining energy sufficiency of a battery-powered robot system is essential for long-term missions.

sub_research_fields.justification: The research specifically addresses the problem of ensuring energy sufficiency for robots in various mission environments, making it a study in the sub-field of energy management within robotics.
sub_research_fields.quote: This capability should be flexible enough to deal with different types of environment and a wide range of missions, while constantly guaranteeing that the robot does not run out of energy.

name.justification: CBFs form the core of the proposed energy sufficiency framework, ensuring that the robot maintains energy efficiency during the mission.
name.quote: we present a modular and mission-agnostic framework that uses a Control Barrier Function (CBF) to guarantee energy sufficiency.

caracteristics.justification: CBFs are used to ensure the safety and efficiency of energy usage in the robot's path planning tasks.
caracteristics.quote: The approach builds upon our previous work, which provides energy-sufficiency guarantees for robots in obstacle-free environments.

name.justification: The Dual-Stage Viewpoint Planner is referenced as a significant exploration planner in relevant literature.
name.quote: Several well-designed exploration planners...the Dual-Stage Viewpoint Planner (Zhu et al. 2021).

caracteristics.justification: Cited as another example of an exploration planner used in robotic path planning.

name.justification: The GBPlanner model is used in the study as an exploration planner to generate paths for robots.
name.quote: Several well-designed exploration planners exist in literature, many of which developed within the scope of the DARPA SubTerranian Challenge (DARPA 2018): the Graph-Based exploration planner (GBPlanner).

caracteristics.justification: GBPlanner is utilized for generating exploration and homing paths for the robot, which is pivotal for the study's experiments.
caracteristics.quote: In this work, we use the GBPlanner to generate both exploration and homing paths.

name.justification: Referenced as another exploration planner used.
name.quote: the motion primitives-based planner (MbPlanner, Dharmadhikari et al. 2020)

caracteristics.justification: MbPlanner is used for generating motion primitives in exploration.
caracteristics.quote: the motion primitives-based planner (MbPlanner, Dharmadhikari et al. 2020)

name.justification: The Next-Best-View planner is referenced as a significant exploration planner in relevant literature.
name.quote: Several well-designed exploration planners exist in literature: the Next-Best-View planner (Bircher et al. 2016).

caracteristics.justification: It is cited as an example of an exploration planner used for path generation in robotics.
caracteristics.quote: Several well-designed exploration planners exist in literature, including the Next-Best-View planner.

name.justification: Referenced as another planner within the scope of the DARPA challenge.

caracteristics.justification: TARE planner is used for exploration as highlighted in the scope of the DARPA SubTerranean Challenge.

name.justification: Buzz scripting language is used for implementing the framework within the simulation environment.
name.quote: Our proposed framework is implemented as a Buzz (Pinciroli and Beltrame 2016) script.

name.justification: ROS is used for handling different modules like mapping, planning, and control within the robot's software setup.
name.quote: We deploy the planning (Gbplanner modules) and controller on ROS, while the remaining system components utilize ROS infrastructure.
